tit.cmt: 定訳不明次の原文で説明されているため、タイトルで補足説明は入れていません。

sen.j: 悌輔騒動（ていすけ そうどう）とは、1872年（明治5年）4月、新潟県および柏崎県（現新潟県）で起きた一揆。
sen.e: Teisuke turmoil was an uprising broke out in Niigata Prefecture and Kashiwazaki Prefecture (present-day Niigata Prefecture) in April 1872.
Teisuke turmoil was an uprising which broke out in Niigata Prefecture and Kashiwazaki Prefecture (present-day Niigata Prefecture) in April 1872.
sen.cmt: 主節の関係代名詞は省略できません。
sen.e: Teisuke turmoil was an uprising which broke out in Niigata Prefecture and Kashiwazaki Prefecture (present-day Niigata Prefecture) in April 1872.

sen.j: 明治新政府に不満を持つ旧会津藩藩士渡辺悌輔らが、大河津分水掘削工事の負担に苦しむ農民等を糾合し、新潟県庁の襲撃を図った事件。
sen.e: It was the incident which was committed by Teisuke WATANABE, a former feudal retainer of Aizu Domain and dissident of Meiji Government and others attempted to attack Niigata Prefectural Office with rallied peasants who were suffering from the burdens of excavation work of Ookozu-Bunsui Canal.

It was the incident in which Teisuke WATANABE, a former feudal retainer of Aizu Domain, and others, being dissatisfied with the Meiji government, rallied peasants who were suffering from the burdens of excavation work of Ookozu-Bunsui Canal, and attempted to attack Niigata Prefectural Office.
sen.cmt: which was committed by…という関係詞節にすると、後のattemptedがつながらなくなります。またdissident of…という言い方もあまりしないようです。
sen.e: It was the incident in which Teisuke WATANABE, a former feudal retainer of Aizu Domain, and others, being dissatisfied with the Meiji government, rallied peasants who were suffering from the burdens of excavation work of Ookozu-Bunsui Canal, and attempted to attack Niigata Prefectural Office.

sen.j: 日本の封建社会における最後にして最大の農民一揆と言われる。
sen.e: The turmoil is said to be the last and largest peasant uprising in the feudal system of Japan.
The turmoil is said to be the last and largest peasant uprising in the feudal system of Japan.
The turmoil is said to be the last and largest peasant uprising in the feudal system of Japan.

sen.j: 一揆は、旧暦4月4日から6日にかけて柏崎県庁へ強訴を行った一行と、4月6日から8日にかけて新潟県庁へ向かった一行とから成る。
sen.e: The uprising was comprised of two groups; one directly petitioned Kashiwazaki Prefectural Office from April 4th to 6th (lunar calendar) to lessen peoples' burdens of the construction, and another went to Niigata Prefectural Office from April 6th to 8th (lunar calendar) to protest about the construction.
sen.cmt: 「強訴を行った」は「工事の負担軽減についての強訴を行った」と解釈し、英訳しました。「向かった」は「抗議のために向かった」と解釈し、英訳しました。
sen.e: The uprising was comprised of two groups; one directly petitioned Kashiwazaki Prefectural Office from April 4th to 6th (lunar calendar) for reduction of peoples' burdens of the construction, and another went to Niigata Prefectural Office from April 6th to 8th (lunar calendar) to protest the construction.
sen.cmt: petitionはto不定詞よりfor…を伴う方が一般的です。またprotestは「に抗議する」の意の他動詞ですので前置詞は不要です。
sen.e: The uprising was comprised of two groups; one directly petitioned Kashiwazaki Prefectural Office from April 4th to 6th (lunar calendar) for reduction of peoples' burdens of the construction, and another went to Niigata Prefectural Office from April 6th to 8th (lunar calendar) to protest the construction.

sen.j: 2つの一揆の間に繋がりは無く、偶発的とするのが通説である。
sen.e: According to the general opinion, two uprisings accidentally happened at once as there is no relation between them.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is widely believed that the two uprisings accidentally happened at the same time and that there was no relation between them.
sen.cmt: 「通説」はgeneral opinionではやや分かりにくいので、「広く信じられている」と言い換えます。「同時に」はat the same timeとした方が明確です。
sen.e: It is widely believed that the two uprisings accidentally happened at the same time and that there was no relation between them.

sen.j: その意味では新潟県側の一揆のみを「悌輔騒動」と呼ぶべきであろうが、事件の性質から合わせて記述する。
sen.e: From that point of view, only Niigata uprising should be called 'Teisuke turmoil', but considering the characteristics of these two incidents, they will be described in this article.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In that respect, only an uprising in Niigata should be called 'Teisuke turmoil', but considering the characteristics of these two incidents, they will be described in this article together.
sen.cmt: この「その意味では」は、あえて「観点」としなくとも、in that respectと表すことができます。
sen.e: In that respect, only an uprising in Niigata should be called 'Teisuke turmoil', but considering the characteristics of these two incidents, they will be described in this article together.

sen.j: 事件の背景
sen.e: Background
sen.cmt: 次の文章から、この項が悌輔騒動の背景を述べていることは明確であり、項目名であることから簡潔に示すため英訳は'Background'のみとしました。
sen.e: Background
Background

sen.j: 新潟平野を流れる信濃川およびその支流である中ノ口川は、かつては毎年のように洪水を引き起こす暴れ川として恐れられて来た。
sen.e: The Shinano River which runs through the Niigata Plain and its tributary, the Nakanokuchi River, used to frighten people because it was known as the river of rampage that caused floods almost every year.

The Shinano River, which runs through the Niigata Plain, and its tributary, the Nakanokuchi River, used to frighten people because they were known as rivers of rampage that caused floods almost every year.
sen.cmt: 「暴れ川として恐れられた」のは信濃川と中ノ口川の2つですのでtheyとすべきです。
sen.e: The Shinano River, which runs through the Niigata Plain, and its tributary, the Nakanokuchi River, used to frighten people because they were known as rivers of rampage that caused floods almost every year.

sen.j: この抜本的治水策として、2つの川の分岐点より上流に当たり、且つ日本海に最も近い現在の燕市分水地区（旧分水町）付近から分水路を掘削する計画が享保年間より江戸幕府に嘆願されてきたが、莫大な工事費と、流域各藩の利害対立により実現しなかった。
sen.e: During Kyoho period and afterward, in order to take a drastic measure against floods, people had supplicated Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by shoguns) for implementation of a plan of controlling flood by excavating diversion aqueducts from around present-day Bunsui District, Tsubame City (former Bunsui-machi), which locates at the upper stream of a fork of the two rivers and the closest area to the Japan Sea, but the plan wasn't executed due to the enormous amount of the construction cost and conflicts of interests among the basin domains.

During Kyoho period and afterward, in order to take a drastic measure against floods, people had petitioned Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by shoguns) for implementation of a plan of controlling floods by excavating diversion aqueducts from around present-day Bunsui District, Tsubame City (former Bunsui-machi), which is located at the upper stream of a fork of the two rivers and the closest to the Japan Sea, but the plan wasn't executed due to the enormous amount of the construction cost and conflicts of interests among the watershed domains.
sen.cmt: supplicate … for～という形はあまり一般的ではないようですので、動詞をpetitionとします。また「～に位置する」はbe locatedと受動態で表す方が一般的です。
sen.e: During Kyoho period and afterward, in order to take a drastic measure against floods, people had petitioned Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by shoguns) for implementation of a plan of controlling floods by excavating diversion aqueducts from around present-day Bunsui District, Tsubame City (former Bunsui-machi), which is located at the upper stream of a fork of the two rivers and the closest to the Japan Sea, but the plan wasn't executed due to the enormous amount of the construction cost and conflicts of interests among the watershed domains.

sen.j: 1868年（慶応4年）新潟平野はまたも洪水に見舞われていた。
sen.e: In 1868, the Niigata Plain again got hit by a flood.
In 1868, the Niigata Plain again got hit by a flood.
In 1868, the Niigata Plain again got hit by a flood.

sen.j: 北越戦争により旧幕府軍が敗退すると、流域の村々は新政府側に分水工事着工の嘆願書を提出し、1869年（明治2年）にようやく着工が認められたが、総工費80万両のうち60万両が地元負担という厳しいものとなった。
sen.e: After the army of former Edo bakufu was defeated in Hokuetsu War, the basin villagers addressed a petition for the commencement of the diversion construction to new Meiji government, and the plan was finally approved in 1869 with a stringent condition loading 600,000-ryo out of total construction cost of 800,000-ryo on the local communities.
sen.cmt: 「旧幕府」は「旧江戸幕府」、「新政府」は「新明治政府」として英訳しました。
sen.e: After the army of former Edo bakufu was defeated in Hokuetsu War, the watershed villagers submitted a petition for the commencement of the diversion construction to new Meiji government, and the plan was finally approved in 1869 on the stringent condition that 600,000-ryo out of the total construction cost 800,000-ryo be paid by the local communities.
sen.cmt: 「提出する」はsubmitとします。「～という条件で」はon condition that～です。
sen.e: After the army of former Edo bakufu was defeated in Hokuetsu War, the watershed villagers submitted a petition for the commencement of the diversion construction to new Meiji government, and the plan was finally approved in 1869 on the stringent condition that 600,000-ryo out of the total construction cost 800,000-ryo be paid by the local communities.

sen.j: 流域の村々には重労働の提供が求められ、更には工事の為の移転を余儀なくされる者、水位の低下による水不足を心配する者もあり、分水工事反対の声が逆に強まっていった。
sen.e: Basin villagers were expected to be engaged in the hard work, and in addition to it, some were forced to move from their own houses due to the construction and some concerned about the water shortage caused by the lowered water level, which led to surging opposition movement against the diversion contraction.

The watershed villagers were requested to provide hard physical labor, and in addition, some were forced to move from their own houses due to the construction and some were concerned about the water shortage caused by the lowered water level, which led to a surging opposition movement against the diversion contraction.
sen.cmt: 「重労働の提供が求められる」にbe expected to～「～することが期待される」では訳として弱すぎます。
sen.e: The watershed villagers were requested to provide hard physical labor, and in addition, some were forced to move from their own houses due to the construction and some were concerned about the water shortage caused by the lowered water level, which led to a surging opposition movement against the diversion contraction.

sen.e: Kashiwazaki Prefecture side
Kashiwazaki Prefecture side

sen.j: 元八王寺村（現燕市）農民の無宿者、川崎九郎次らは、1872年（明治5年）3月頃より流域に分水工事反対の決起を呼び掛ける落し文を行っていた。
sen.e: Kuroji KAWASAKI, a homeless wanderer, originally a peasant from Hachioji Village (present-day Tsubame City), and others started distributing Otoshibumi (letters dropped in the road: fliers) in the basin area from around March 1872 encouraging people to rally against the construction.
sen.cmt: 「無宿者」の訳は'homeless wanderer'としています。
sen.e: Kuroji KAWASAKI, a homeless wanderer who had originally been a peasant in Hachioji Village (present-day Tsubame City), and others started distributing Otoshibumi (letters dropped in the road: fliers) in the watershed area from around March 1872 encouraging people to rally against the construction.
sen.cmt: 「元八王寺村（現燕市）農民の無宿者」をまとめて訳出し、Kuroji KAWASAKIと同格とします。

sen.j: （後の調書によれば、彼は新政府転覆を企てる元米沢藩藩士、木下三左衛門の指示を受けたとあるが、この人物については不明である。）
sen.e: (According to the record which was taken after the arrest of KAWASAKI, he followed the instruction of Sanzaemon KINOSHITA, a former feudal retainer of Yonezawa Domain, but no precise information about him was found.)
sen.cmt: 「木下三左衛門」の読みは「きのしたさんざえもん」としています。
sen.e: (According to a statement taken later, KAWASAKI followed the instruction of Sanzaemon KINOSHITA, a former feudal retainer of Yonezawa Domain who was conspiring to topple the new government, but no precise information about him was found.)
sen.cmt: 日本文には「逮捕後」とは述べられていませんのでlaterとしておきます。「新政府転覆を企てる」を訳出します。
sen.e: (According to a statement taken later, KAWASAKI followed the instruction of Sanzaemon KINOSHITA, a former feudal retainer of Yonezawa Domain who was conspiring to topple the new government, but no precise information about him was found.)

sen.j: 4月3日夜、早鐘を合図に現在の巻潟東インターチェンジ付近に千数百名の一揆勢が集結し、道々周辺の農民を糾合しながら柏崎県庁（現柏崎市）へ強訴に向かった。
sen.e: On April 3rd at night, over a thousand uprising people concentrated around present-day Makikata Higashi interchange at the sound of a fire bell, and went to Kashiwazaki Prefectural Office (present-day Kashiwazaki City) to file a direct petition as gathering neighborhood peasants on their way to the office.

On the night of April 3rd, more than a thousand uprising people concentrated around the present-day Makikata Higashi interchange at the sound of a fire bell, and marched toward Kashiwazaki Prefectural Office (present-day Kashiwazaki City) to file a direct petition, while peasants in the neighborhood joined the march.
sen.cmt: 「日付」＋「夜」の表記法を修正しました。「糾合しながら」as gathering…はやや分かりにくいですので修正します。
sen.e: On the night of April 3rd, more than a thousand uprising people concentrated around the present-day Makikata Higashi interchange at the sound of a fire bell, and marched toward Kashiwazaki Prefectural Office (present-day Kashiwazaki City) to file a direct petition, while peasants in the neighborhood joined the march.

sen.j: 一説には、最盛時には9千名にも達したとされるが、途中逃げ帰るものも多く、5日午後に柏崎に到着した時には4～6千名ほどであったとされる。
sen.e: It is said that the number of people reached 9,000 at its peak, but eventually about 4,000-6,000 people reached Kashiwazaki City on 5th in the afternoon as many had left the party on their way.
It is said that the number of people reached 9,000 at its peak, but eventually about 4,000-6,000 people reached Kashiwazaki City on the afternoon of 5th as many people had left on their way.
sen.cmt: 「日付」＋「午後」の表記法を修正しました。
sen.e: It is said that the number of people reached 9,000 at its peak, but eventually about 4,000-6,000 people reached Kashiwazaki City on the afternoon of 5th as many people had left on their way.

sen.j: 一揆勢は県庁側役人に次のような嘆願書を提出した。
sen.e: The uprising group handed a petition that included following requests to Sobayaku (Secretary) of the Prefectural Office.
The uprising group handed Sobayaku (Secretary) of the Prefectural Office a petition that included the following requests.
sen.cmt: to Sobayaku…を文末に置くとhandedに続くことが分かりにくくなりますので、文構造を修正しました。
sen.e: The uprising group handed Sobayaku (Secretary) of the Prefectural Office a petition that included the following requests.

sen.j: 分水工事の負担の免除。
sen.e: To exempt the load of diversion construction.
To exempt the load of diversion construction.
To exempt the load of diversion construction.

sen.j: 氏子・檀家の負担となる社寺の免税。
sen.e: To exempt the tax on shrines and temples as those taxes would eventually be paid by shrine and Buddhist parishioners.
To exempt the tax on shrines and temples as those taxes would eventually be paid by shrine and Buddhist parishioners.
To exempt the tax on shrines and temples as those taxes would eventually be paid by shrine and Buddhist parishioners.

sen.j: 年貢を旧幕府時代の水準への据置き。
sen.e: To keep the same amount of nengu (annual tribute, land tax) as the level of former Edo bakufu era.
To keep the same amount of nengu (annual tribute, land tax) as the level of former Edo bakufu era.
To keep the same amount of nengu (annual tribute, land tax) as the level of former Edo bakufu era.

sen.j: 外国との交易差止め。
sen.e: To halt trades with foreign countries.
To halt trades with foreign countries.
To halt trades with foreign countries.

sen.j: 分水工事は官費で行い、労賃を滞りなく支払うこと。
sen.e: To carry out the diversion construction at the public expense and pay the wages without any delay.
To carry out the diversion construction at the public expense and pay the wages without any delay.
To carry out the diversion construction at the public expense and pay the wages without any delay.

sen.j: 船などでの廻米による年貢を止め、地元で納付するよう改めること。
sen.e: To pay nengu at the local area instead of transporting it by ship, etc. to other location.
sen.cmt: 「廻米」は「他の場所に年貢を輸送すること」と英文で記載しています。
sen.e: To pay nengu at the local area instead of transporting it by ship, etc. to another location.

sen.e: To pay nengu at the local area instead of transporting it by ship, etc. to another location.

sen.j: 村役人を公選制とすること。
sen.e: To elect the village officers through public election system.
To elect the village officers through public election system.
To elect the village officers through public election system.

sen.j: 県側は急遽浪人らを集め、見廻隊を結成して対応に当たったが、衝突には至らなかった。
sen.e: The Prefectural Office hastily mustered ronins (masterless samurai) to organize patrol squads in order to deal with the turmoil, but both sides never clashed.

sen.j: 翌6日夜、県側は一揆首謀者の宿舎を急襲し、彼等を捕縛した。
sen.e: On the next day, 6th at night, the Prefectural Office made a raid on a camp where ringleaders of uprising stayed, and arrested them.
On the night of the next day, 6th, the Prefectural Office made a raid on a camp where ringleaders of the uprising stayed, and arrested them.

sen.j: 元会津藩士の渡辺悌輔および月岡村（現三条市）安正寺の元住職で元桑名藩藩兵の月岡帯刀らは加茂市の農民等と図り、4月4日より三条・加茂一帯に決起を呼び掛ける落し文を行った。
sen.e: Teisuke WATANABE, a former feudal retainer of Aizu Domain, and Tatewaki TSUKIOKA, a former chief priest of Ansho-ji Temple in Tsukioka village (present-day Sanjo City) and former feudal soldier of Kuwana Domain, distributed Otoshibumi (fliers) from April 4th with peasants from Kamo City in order to appeal people in Sanjo and Kamo area for rally.
sen.cmt: 「月岡帯刀」の読みは「つきおかたてわき」、「安正寺」の読みは「あんしょうじ」としています。「藩兵」は定訳不明のため'feudal soldier'と訳しています。
sen.e: Teisuke WATANABE, a former feudal retainer of Aizu Domain, and Tatewaki TSUKIOKA, a former chief priest of Ansho-ji Temple in Tsukioka village (present-day Sanjo City) and former feudal soldier of Kuwana Domain, conspired with farmers in Kamo City to distribute Otoshibumi all over Sanjo and Kamo areas from April 4th in order to urge people to rise in revolt.
sen.cmt: 「加茂市の農民等と図り」「三条・加茂一帯に落とし文を行った」を明確に訳出します。
sen.e: Teisuke WATANABE, a former feudal retainer of Aizu Domain, and Tatewaki TSUKIOKA, a former chief priest of Ansho-ji Temple in Tsukioka village (present-day Sanjo City) and former feudal soldier of Kuwana Domain, conspired with farmers in Kamo City to distribute Otoshibumi all over Sanjo and Kamo areas from April 4th in order to urge people to rise in revolt.

sen.j: 6日未明、渡辺らは村々を強請して約千名の一揆勢を連れ、東本願寺三条別院に集結した。
sen.e: Before dawn of 6th, Watanabe and other members forced villagers to participate in the uprising and concentrated at the branch temple of Higashi Hongan-ji Temple in Sanjo with the uprising party comprised of about one thousand people.

Before dawn of 6th, WATANABE and other members visited villages to mobilize villagers for the uprising, and concentrated at the branch temple of Higashi Hongan-ji Temple in Sanjo with the uprising party comprised of about one thousand people.
sen.cmt: 人名の姓は大文字で表記します。「村々を回った」の意を訳出します。
sen.e: Before dawn of 6th, WATANABE and other members visited villages to mobilize villagers for the uprising, and concentrated at the branch temple of Higashi Hongan-ji Temple in Sanjo with the uprising party comprised of about one thousand people.

sen.j: 渡辺等は「天照皇 徳川恢復朝敵奸佞征伐」の旗を掲げ、7日朝より新潟県庁へ向けて北上した。
sen.e: WATANABE and other members headed north to Niigata Prefectural Office on 7th in the morning hoisting the flag that read 'In the name of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess), we restore the dignity and honor of Tokugawa bakufu and conquer unrighteous traitor of the Emperor.'
sen.cmt: 「天照皇 徳川恢復朝敵奸佞征伐」は「天照大神の名のもと、徳川幕府の権威を取り戻し、邪な考えを持つ朝敵を征伐する」と解釈しました。
sen.e: WATANABE and other members headed north toward Niigata Prefectural Office on the morning of 7th hoisting the flag that read 'In the name of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess), we wil restore the dignity and honor of the Tokugawa shogunate and conquer unrighteous traitor of the Emperor.'
sen.cmt: 「日付」＋「朝」の表記法を修正します。
sen.e: WATANABE and other members headed north toward Niigata Prefectural Office on the morning of 7th hoisting the flag that read 'In the name of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess), we wil restore the dignity and honor of the Tokugawa shogunate and conquer unrighteous traitor of the Emperor.'

sen.j: 最盛時には5～6千名だったとされる一揆勢の一部は暴徒と化して略奪・放火や打壊しを行い、事態収拾に向かった県庁役人や庄屋を殺害した。
sen.e: Part of the uprising party, which was said to be 5,000 - 6,000 people involved at its peak, became violent and committed looting, arson and destroyed hoses, then killed Prefectural officials and shoya (village headmen) who tried to put the situation under control.

Part of the uprising party, which was said to consist of 5,000 - 6,000 people at its peak, became violent and committed looting, arson and destroyed houses, then killed Prefectural officials and shoya (village headmen) who tried to put the situation under control.
sen.cmt: 「5～6千名だった」はconsist ofを用いた方がはっきりします。Housesのミススペリングを修正しました。
sen.e: Part of the uprising party, which was said to consist of 5,000 - 6,000 people at its peak, became violent and committed looting, arson and destroyed houses, then killed Prefectural officials and shoya (village headmen) who tried to put the situation under control.

sen.j: 県側は一揆勢が新潟町に入るのを阻止するため平島（現新潟市）に軍を集め、8日午後、北上してきた一揆勢に威嚇射撃を行い、突撃しようとした首謀者の1人を射殺した。
sen.e: The Prefectural Office mustered an army in Heijima (present-day Niigata City) in order to prevent the uprising party from entering Niigata-machi, and on 8th in the afternoon, fired warning shots against the uprising party moving toward the north, shooting one of the ringleader who intended to charge.
sen.cmt: 「平島」の読みは「へいじま」、「新潟町」の読みは「にいがたまち」としています。
sen.e: The Prefectural Office mustered an army in Heijima (present-day Niigata City) in order to prevent the uprising party from entering Niigata-machi, and on the afternoon of 8th, fired warning shots against the uprising party moving toward the north, shooting one of the ringleaders who intended to charge.
sen.cmt: 「日付」＋「午後」の表記法を修正しました。One ofの後には限定詞つきの複数名詞が来ます。
sen.e: The Prefectural Office mustered an army in Heijima (present-day Niigata City) in order to prevent the uprising party from entering Niigata-machi, and on the afternoon of 8th, fired warning shots against the uprising party moving toward the north, shooting one of the ringleaders who intended to charge.

sen.j: 一揆勢は潰走し、首謀者や殺害の下手人はほとんどが数日の内に捕縛された。
sen.e: The defeated uprising party fled in disorder, and its ringleaders and murderers were arrested within a few days.

sen.j: 一揆の後、新潟県令平松時厚は更迭され、新たに楠本正隆が赴任した。
sen.e: After the turmoil, Tokiatsu HIRAMATSU, Kenrei (governor) of Niigata Prefecture was dismissed, and Masataka KUSUMOTO was assigned to the post.
sen.cmt: 「平松時厚」の読みは「ひらまつときあつ」、「楠本正隆」の読みは「くすもとまさたか」としています。

sen.j: 渡辺悌輔、月岡帯刀、川崎九郎次等、捕縛された首謀者と殺害の下手人等の合わせて7名はいずれも9月10日に処刑された。
sen.e: Seven criminals including Teisuke WATANABE, Tatewaki TSUKIOKA, Kuroji KAWASAKI and the other arrested ringleaders and murderers were put to death on September 10th.

sen.j: 柏崎県は後に新潟県へ併合された。
sen.e: Later Kashiwazaki Prefecture was merged to Niigata Prefecture.

sen.j: 一揆の後中断していた分水工事は6月下旬に再開されたが、オランダ技師リンドーの報告書などもあり1875年（明治8年）に中止された。
sen.e: The diversion construction which was suspended during the turmoil was restarted in late June, but was canceled in 1875 due to the report written by a Dutch engineer, Lindo.

sen.j: 工事の再着工は1907年（明治40年）、完成は実に一揆から52年後の1924年（大正13年）のことである。
